unnormalised: Planning a road trip in India? Buckle up, buttercup, because you’re in for a ride! It's not just about scenic views and chai stops; it’s about navigating the organised chaos that is Indian roads. Forget GPS; you'll need divine intervention and a healthy dose of "chalta hai" attitude. Expect delays – and I mean *major* delays. Google Maps says 6 hrs from Bangalore to Mysore? Double it. Minimum. Maybe triple it if it's a long weekend or near Diwali. Remember that 7 hrs you saved up from work? Consider it burned.

unnormalised: First things first, vehicle check. Forget fancy sports cars; invest in a sturdy SUV that can handle potholes the size of small craters. Make sure you've got a spare tyre, because trust me, you'll need it. Several, if you're attempting a Himalayan road trip. Also, honking is a love language here. Learn to speak it fluently. A short "pip" is a friendly hello; a sustained blast is a “get out of my way, you tuk-tuk!" (Auto-rickshaws are a whole other level of crazy BTW. Think Formula 1 meets bumper cars). Remember to check that fuel gauge- you don't want to be stranded and looking for petrol at 2:00 AM.

unnormalised: Then there are the unexpected pit stops. You’ll encounter cows casually chilling in the middle of the highway, requiring a polite but firm "excuse me, ma'am." You’ll find entire families piled onto motorbikes, defying the laws of physics (and probably traffic). And don't even get me started on the roadside dhabas. The food is amazing (seriously, try the butter chicken at a dhaba near Murthal), but hygiene standards are...well, let's just say pack some antacids and hope for the best. That Rs. 25 chai might be your undoing.

unnormalised: And let's discuss the traffic. It's less of a flow and more of a free-for-all. Lanes are merely suggestions. Overtaking is an art form. Indicators are optional. And speed limits? They're just guidelines for tourists, really. Keep your eyes peeled for unexpected speed bumps, especially near smaller villages. You'll be cruising at 80 kmph one moment and then nearly airborne the next. So, drive defensively, always anticipate the worst, and maybe invest in a good dashcam.

unnormalised: But amidst the madness, there’s magic. The breathtaking landscapes, the vibrant culture, the unexpected friendships you’ll make along the way. Sharing a cup of chai with a truck driver at 3 AM, haggling for souvenirs at a roadside stall, witnessing a stunning sunrise over the Himalayas – these are the moments that make an Indian road trip unforgettable.

unnormalised: So, pack your bags, charge your phone, and embrace the chaos. An Indian road trip isn't just a journey; it's an adventure. Just remember to take everything with a pinch of salt – and a whole lot of patience. The journey might take 2X the amount of time you predicted, but you will love it. You'll laugh, you'll cry, you'll question your sanity, and you'll come back with stories to tell for years to come. Safe travels, and may the odds be ever in your favour!
